intro: Microstylis polyblephara, commonly known as the two-eyed grass, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, commonly known as the sedge family, and is characterized by its slender, grass-like appearance. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered spikes of pale green to reddish-brown flowers. Microstylis polyblephara is typically found in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds, where it thrives in moist, well-drained soils. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, supporting various insect and bird life.
